39/**
40 * @fileoverview This code was ported from the Dojo Toolkit
41 http://dojotoolkit.org and modified slightly for Closure.
42 *
43 * goog.dom.query is a relatively full-featured CSS3 query function. It is
44 * designed to take any valid CSS3 selector and return the nodes matching
45 * the selector. To do this quickly, it processes queries in several
46 * steps, applying caching where profitable.
47 * The steps (roughly in reverse order of the way they appear in the code):
48 * 1.) check to see if we already have a "query dispatcher"
49 * - if so, use that with the given parameterization. Skip to step 4.
50 * 2.) attempt to determine which branch to dispatch the query to:
51 * - JS (optimized DOM iteration)
52 * - native (FF3.1, Safari 3.2+, Chrome, some IE 8 doctypes). If native,
53 * skip to step 4, using a stub dispatcher for QSA queries.
54 * 3.) tokenize and convert to executable "query dispatcher"
55 * assembled as a chain of "yes/no" test functions pertaining to
56 * a section of a simple query statement (".blah:nth-child(odd)"
57 * but not "div div", which is 2 simple statements).
58 * 4.) the resulting query dispatcher is called in the passed scope
59 * (by default the top-level document)
60 * - for DOM queries, this results in a recursive, top-down
61 * evaluation of nodes based on each simple query section
62 * - querySelectorAll is used instead of DOM where possible. If a query
63 * fails in this mode, it is re-run against the DOM evaluator and all
64 * future queries using the same selector evaluate against the DOM branch
65 * too.
66 * 5.) matched nodes are pruned to ensure they are unique
67 * @deprecated This is an all-software query selector. When developing for
68 * recent browsers, use document.querySelector. See information at
69 * http://caniuse.com/queryselector and
70 * https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/DOM/Document.querySelector .
71 */
72
73goog.provide('goog.dom.query');
74
75goog.require('goog.array');
76goog.require('goog.dom');
77goog.require('goog.functions');
78goog.require('goog.string');
79goog.require('goog.userAgent');
80
81 /**
82 * Returns nodes which match the given CSS3 selector, searching the
83 * entire document by default but optionally taking a node to scope
84 * the search by.
85 *
86 * dojo.query() is the swiss army knife of DOM node manipulation in
87 * Dojo. Much like Prototype's "$$" (bling-bling) function or JQuery's
88 * "$" function, dojo.query provides robust, high-performance
89 * CSS-based node selector support with the option of scoping searches
90 * to a particular sub-tree of a document.
91 *
92 * Supported Selectors:
93 * --------------------
94 *
95 * dojo.query() supports a rich set of CSS3 selectors, including:
96 *
97 * * class selectors (e.g., `.foo`)
98 * * node type selectors like `span`
99 * * ` ` descendant selectors
100 * * `>` child element selectors
101 * * `#foo` style ID selectors
102 * * `*` universal selector
103 * * `~`, the immediately preceded-by sibling selector
104 * * `+`, the preceded-by sibling selector
105 * * attribute queries:
106 * | * `[foo]` attribute presence selector
107 * | * `[foo='bar']` attribute value exact match
108 * | * `[foo~='bar']` attribute value list item match
109 * | * `[foo^='bar']` attribute start match
110 * | * `[foo$='bar']` attribute end match
111 * | * `[foo*='bar']` attribute substring match
112 * * `:first-child`, `:last-child` positional selectors
113 * * `:empty` content empty selector
114 * * `:empty` content empty selector
115 * * `:nth-child(n)`, `:nth-child(2n+1)` style positional calculations
116 * * `:nth-child(even)`, `:nth-child(odd)` positional selectors
117 * * `:not(...)` negation pseudo selectors
118 *
119 * Any legal combination of these selectors will work with
120 * `dojo.query()`, including compound selectors ("," delimited).
121 * Very complex and useful searches can be constructed with this
122 * palette of selectors.
123 *
124 * Unsupported Selectors:
125 * ----------------------
126 *
127 * While dojo.query handles many CSS3 selectors, some fall outside of
128 * what's reasonable for a programmatic node querying engine to
129 * handle. Currently unsupported selectors include:
130 *
131 * * namespace-differentiated selectors of any form
132 * * all `::` pseudo-element selectors
133 * * certain pseudo-selectors which don't get a lot of day-to-day use:
134 * | * `:root`, `:lang()`, `:target`, `:focus`
135 * * all visual and state selectors:
136 * | * `:root`, `:active`, `:hover`, `:visited`, `:link`,
137 * `:enabled`, `:disabled`, `:checked`
138 * * `:*-of-type` pseudo selectors
139 *
140 * dojo.query and XML Documents:
141 * -----------------------------
142 *
143 * `dojo.query` currently only supports searching XML documents
144 * whose tags and attributes are 100% lower-case. This is a known
145 * limitation and will [be addressed soon]
146 * (http://trac.dojotoolkit.org/ticket/3866)
147 *
148 * Non-selector Queries:
149 * ---------------------
150 *
151 * If something other than a String is passed for the query,
152 * `dojo.query` will return a new array constructed from
153 * that parameter alone and all further processing will stop. This
154 * means that if you have a reference to a node or array or nodes, you
155 * can quickly construct a new array of nodes from the original by
156 * calling `dojo.query(node)` or `dojo.query(array)`.
157 *
158 * example:
159 * search the entire document for elements with the class "foo":
160 * | dojo.query(".foo");
161 * these elements will match:
162 * | <span class="foo"></span>
163 * | <span class="foo bar"></span>
164 * | <p class="thud foo"></p>
165 * example:
166 * search the entire document for elements with the classes "foo" *and*
167 * "bar":
168 * | dojo.query(".foo.bar");
169 * these elements will match:
170 * | <span class="foo bar"></span>
171 * while these will not:
172 * | <span class="foo"></span>
173 * | <p class="thud foo"></p>
174 * example:
175 * find `<span>` elements which are descendants of paragraphs and
176 * which have a "highlighted" class:
177 * | dojo.query("p span.highlighted");
178 * the innermost span in this fragment matches:
179 * | <p class="foo">
180 * | <span>...
181 * | <span class="highlighted foo bar">...</span>
182 * | </span>
183 * | </p>
184 * example:
185 * find all odd table rows inside of the table
186 * `#tabular_data`, using the `>` (direct child) selector to avoid
187 * affecting any nested tables:
188 * | dojo.query("#tabular_data > tbody > tr:nth-child(odd)");
189 *
190 * @param {string|Array} query The CSS3 expression to match against.
191 * For details on the syntax of CSS3 selectors, see
192 * http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-selectors/#selectors.
193 * @param {(string|Node)=} opt_root A Node (or node id) to scope the search
194 * from (optional).
195 * @return { {length: number} } The elements that matched the query.
196 *
197 * @deprecated This is an all-software query selector. Use
198 * document.querySelector. See
199 * https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/DOM/Document.querySelector .
200 */
201goog.dom.query = (function() {
202 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
203 // Global utilities
204 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
205
206 var cssCaseBug = (goog.userAgent.WEBKIT &&
207 ((goog.dom.getDocument().compatMode) == 'BackCompat')
208 );
209
210 var legacyIE = goog.userAgent.IE && !goog.userAgent.isVersionOrHigher('9');
211
212 // On browsers that support the "children" collection we can avoid a lot of
213 // iteration on chaff (non-element) nodes.
214 var childNodesName = !!goog.dom.getDocument().firstChild['children'] ?
215 'children' :
216 'childNodes';
217
218 var specials = '>~+';
219
220 // Global thunk to determine whether we should treat the current query as
221 // case sensitive or not. This switch is flipped by the query evaluator based
222 // on the document passed as the context to search.
223 var caseSensitive = false;
224
225
226 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
227 // Tokenizer
228 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
229
230 var getQueryParts = function(query) {
231 // summary:
232 // state machine for query tokenization
233 // description:
234 // instead of using a brittle and slow regex-based CSS parser,
235 // dojo.query implements an AST-style query representation. This
236 // representation is only generated once per query. For example,
237 // the same query run multiple times or under different root nodes
238 // does not re-parse the selector expression but instead uses the
239 // cached data structure. The state machine implemented here
240 // terminates on the last " " (space) character and returns an
241 // ordered array of query component structures (or "parts"). Each
242 // part represents an operator or a simple CSS filtering
243 // expression. The structure for parts is documented in the code
244 // below.
245
246
247 // NOTE:
248 // this code is designed to run fast and compress well. Sacrifices
249 // to readability and maintainability have been made.
250 if (specials.indexOf(query.slice(-1)) >= 0) {
251 // If we end with a ">", "+", or "~", that means we're implicitly
252 // searching all children, so make it explicit.
253 query += ' * '
254 } else {
255 // if you have not provided a terminator, one will be provided for
256 // you...
257 query += ' ';
258 }
259
260 var ts = function(/*Integer*/ s, /*Integer*/ e) {
261 // trim and slice.
262
263 // take an index to start a string slice from and an end position
264 // and return a trimmed copy of that sub-string
265 return goog.string.trim(query.slice(s, e));
266 };
267
268 // The overall data graph of the full query, as represented by queryPart
269 // objects.
270 var queryParts = [];
271
272
273 // state keeping vars
274 var inBrackets = -1,
275 inParens = -1,
276 inMatchFor = -1,
277 inPseudo = -1,
278 inClass = -1,
279 inId = -1,
280 inTag = -1,
281 lc = '',
282 cc = '',
283 pStart;
284
285 // iteration vars
286 var x = 0, // index in the query
287 ql = query.length,
288 currentPart = null, // data structure representing the entire clause
289 cp = null; // the current pseudo or attr matcher
290
291 // several temporary variables are assigned to this structure during a
292 // potential sub-expression match:
293 // attr:
294 // a string representing the current full attribute match in a
295 // bracket expression
296 // type:
297 // if there's an operator in a bracket expression, this is
298 // used to keep track of it
299 // value:
300 // the internals of parenthetical expression for a pseudo. for
301 // :nth-child(2n+1), value might be '2n+1'
302
303 var endTag = function() {
304 // called when the tokenizer hits the end of a particular tag name.
305 // Re-sets state variables for tag matching and sets up the matcher
306 // to handle the next type of token (tag or operator).
307 if (inTag >= 0) {
308 var tv = (inTag == x) ? null : ts(inTag, x);
309 if (specials.indexOf(tv) < 0) {
310 currentPart.tag = tv;
311 } else {
312 currentPart.oper = tv;
313 }
314 inTag = -1;
315 }
316 };
317
318 var endId = function() {
319 // Called when the tokenizer might be at the end of an ID portion of a
320 // match.
321 if (inId >= 0) {
322 currentPart.id = ts(inId, x).replace(/\\/g, '');
323 inId = -1;
324 }
325 };
326
327 var endClass = function() {
328 // Called when the tokenizer might be at the end of a class name
329 // match. CSS allows for multiple classes, so we augment the
330 // current item with another class in its list.
331 if (inClass >= 0) {
332 currentPart.classes.push(ts(inClass + 1, x).replace(/\\/g, ''));
333 inClass = -1;
334 }
335 };
336
337 var endAll = function() {
338 // at the end of a simple fragment, so wall off the matches
339 endId(); endTag(); endClass();
340 };
341
342 var endPart = function() {
343 endAll();
344 if (inPseudo >= 0) {
345 currentPart.pseudos.push({ name: ts(inPseudo + 1, x) });
346 }
347 // Hint to the selector engine to tell it whether or not it
348 // needs to do any iteration. Many simple selectors don't, and
349 // we can avoid significant construction-time work by advising
350 // the system to skip them.
351 currentPart.loops = currentPart.pseudos.length ||
352 currentPart.attrs.length ||
353 currentPart.classes.length;
354
355 // save the full expression as a string
356 currentPart.oquery = currentPart.query = ts(pStart, x);
357
358
359 // otag/tag are hints to suggest to the system whether or not
360 // it's an operator or a tag. We save a copy of otag since the
361 // tag name is cast to upper-case in regular HTML matches. The
362 // system has a global switch to figure out if the current
363 // expression needs to be case sensitive or not and it will use
364 // otag or tag accordingly
365 currentPart.otag = currentPart.tag = (currentPart.oper) ?
366 null :
367 (currentPart.tag || '*');
368
369 if (currentPart.tag) {
370 // if we're in a case-insensitive HTML doc, we likely want
371 // the toUpperCase when matching on element.tagName. If we
372 // do it here, we can skip the string op per node
373 // comparison
374 currentPart.tag = currentPart.tag.toUpperCase();
375 }
376
377 // add the part to the list
378 if (queryParts.length && (queryParts[queryParts.length - 1].oper)) {
379 // operators are always infix, so we remove them from the
380 // list and attach them to the next match. The evaluator is
381 // responsible for sorting out how to handle them.
382 currentPart.infixOper = queryParts.pop();
383 currentPart.query = currentPart.infixOper.query + ' ' +
384 currentPart.query;
385 }
386 queryParts.push(currentPart);
387
388 currentPart = null;
389 }
390
391 // iterate over the query, character by character, building up a
392 // list of query part objects
393 for (; lc = cc, cc = query.charAt(x), x < ql; x++) {
394 // cc: the current character in the match
395 // lc: the last character (if any)
396
397 // someone is trying to escape something, so don't try to match any
398 // fragments. We assume we're inside a literal.
399 if (lc == '\\') {
400 continue;
401 }
402 if (!currentPart) { // a part was just ended or none has yet been created
403 // NOTE: I hate all this alloc, but it's shorter than writing tons of
404 // if's
405 pStart = x;
406 // rules describe full CSS sub-expressions, like:
407 // #someId
408 // .className:first-child
409 // but not:
410 // thinger > div.howdy[type=thinger]
411 // the individual components of the previous query would be
412 // split into 3 parts that would be represented a structure
413 // like:
414 // [
415 // {
416 // query: 'thinger',
417 // tag: 'thinger',
418 // },
419 // {
420 // query: 'div.howdy[type=thinger]',
421 // classes: ['howdy'],
422 // infixOper: {
423 // query: '>',
424 // oper: '>',
425 // }
426 // },
427 // ]
428 currentPart = {
429 query: null, // the full text of the part's rule
430 pseudos: [], // CSS supports multiple pseudo-class matches in a single
431 // rule
432 attrs: [], // CSS supports multi-attribute match, so we need an array
433 classes: [], // class matches may be additive,
434 // e.g.: .thinger.blah.howdy
435 tag: null, // only one tag...
436 oper: null, // ...or operator per component. Note that these wind up
437 // being exclusive.
438 id: null, // the id component of a rule
439 getTag: function() {
440 return (caseSensitive) ? this.otag : this.tag;
441 }
442 };
443
444 // if we don't have a part, we assume we're going to start at
445 // the beginning of a match, which should be a tag name. This
446 // might fault a little later on, but we detect that and this
447 // iteration will still be fine.
448 inTag = x;
449 }
450
451 if (inBrackets >= 0) {
452 // look for a the close first
453 if (cc == ']') { // if we're in a [...] clause and we end, do assignment
454 if (!cp.attr) {
455 // no attribute match was previously begun, so we
456 // assume this is an attribute existence match in the
457 // form of [someAttributeName]
458 cp.attr = ts(inBrackets + 1, x);
459 } else {
460 // we had an attribute already, so we know that we're
461 // matching some sort of value, as in [attrName=howdy]
462 cp.matchFor = ts((inMatchFor || inBrackets + 1), x);
463 }
464 var cmf = cp.matchFor;
465 if (cmf) {
466 // try to strip quotes from the matchFor value. We want
467 // [attrName=howdy] to match the same
468 // as [attrName = 'howdy' ]
469 if ((cmf.charAt(0) == '"') || (cmf.charAt(0) == "'")) {
470 cp.matchFor = cmf.slice(1, -1);
471 }
472 }
473 // end the attribute by adding it to the list of attributes.
474 currentPart.attrs.push(cp);
475 cp = null; // necessary?
476 inBrackets = inMatchFor = -1;
477 } else if (cc == '=') {
478 // if the last char was an operator prefix, make sure we
479 // record it along with the '=' operator.
480 var addToCc = ('|~^$*'.indexOf(lc) >= 0) ? lc : '';
481 cp.type = addToCc + cc;
482 cp.attr = ts(inBrackets + 1, x - addToCc.length);
483 inMatchFor = x + 1;
484 }
485 // now look for other clause parts
486 } else if (inParens >= 0) {
487 // if we're in a parenthetical expression, we need to figure
488 // out if it's attached to a pseudo-selector rule like
489 // :nth-child(1)
490 if (cc == ')') {
491 if (inPseudo >= 0) {
492 cp.value = ts(inParens + 1, x);
493 }
494 inPseudo = inParens = -1;
495 }
496 } else if (cc == '#') {
497 // start of an ID match
498 endAll();
499 inId = x + 1;
500 } else if (cc == '.') {
501 // start of a class match
502 endAll();
503 inClass = x;
504 } else if (cc == ':') {
505 // start of a pseudo-selector match
506 endAll();
507 inPseudo = x;
508 } else if (cc == '[') {
509 // start of an attribute match.
510 endAll();
511 inBrackets = x;
512 // provide a new structure for the attribute match to fill-in
513 cp = {
514 /*=====
515 attr: null, type: null, matchFor: null
516 =====*/
517 };
518 } else if (cc == '(') {
519 // we really only care if we've entered a parenthetical
520 // expression if we're already inside a pseudo-selector match
521 if (inPseudo >= 0) {
522 // provide a new structure for the pseudo match to fill-in
523 cp = {
524 name: ts(inPseudo + 1, x),
525 value: null
526 }
527 currentPart.pseudos.push(cp);
528 }
529 inParens = x;
530 } else if (
531 (cc == ' ') &&
532 // if it's a space char and the last char is too, consume the
533 // current one without doing more work
534 (lc != cc)
535 ) {
536 endPart();
537 }
538 }
539 return queryParts;
540 };
541
542
543 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
544 // DOM query infrastructure
545 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
546
547 var agree = function(first, second) {
548 // the basic building block of the yes/no chaining system. agree(f1,
549 // f2) generates a new function which returns the boolean results of
550 // both of the passed functions to a single logical-anded result. If
551 // either are not passed, the other is used exclusively.
552 if (!first) {
553 return second;
554 }
555 if (!second) {
556 return first;
557 }
558
559 return function() {
560 return first.apply(window, arguments) && second.apply(window, arguments);
561 }
562 };
563
564 /**
565 * @param {Array=} opt_arr
566 */
567 function getArr(i, opt_arr) {
568 // helps us avoid array alloc when we don't need it
569 var r = opt_arr || [];
570 if (i) {
571 r.push(i);
572 }
573 return r;
574 };
575
576 var isElement = function(n) {
577 return (1 == n.nodeType);
578 };
579
580 // FIXME: need to coalesce getAttr with defaultGetter
581 var blank = '';
582 var getAttr = function(elem, attr) {
583 if (!elem) {
584 return blank;
585 }
586 if (attr == 'class') {
587 return elem.className || blank;
588 }
589 if (attr == 'for') {
590 return elem.htmlFor || blank;
591 }
592 if (attr == 'style') {
593 return elem.style.cssText || blank;
594 }
595 return (caseSensitive ? elem.getAttribute(attr) :
596 elem.getAttribute(attr, 2)) || blank;
597 };
598
599 var attrs = {
600 '*=': function(attr, value) {
601 return function(elem) {
602 // E[foo*="bar"]
603 // an E element whose "foo" attribute value contains
604 // the substring "bar"
605 return (getAttr(elem, attr).indexOf(value) >= 0);
606 }
607 },
608 '^=': function(attr, value) {
609 // E[foo^="bar"]
610 // an E element whose "foo" attribute value begins exactly
611 // with the string "bar"
612 return function(elem) {
613 return (getAttr(elem, attr).indexOf(value) == 0);
614 }
615 },
616 '$=': function(attr, value) {
617 // E[foo$="bar"]
618 // an E element whose "foo" attribute value ends exactly
619 // with the string "bar"
620 var tval = ' ' + value;
621 return function(elem) {
622 var ea = ' ' + getAttr(elem, attr);
623 return (ea.lastIndexOf(value) == (ea.length - value.length));
624 }
625 },
626 '~=': function(attr, value) {
627 // E[foo~="bar"]
628 // an E element whose "foo" attribute value is a list of
629 // space-separated values, one of which is exactly equal
630 // to "bar"
631
632 var tval = ' ' + value + ' ';
633 return function(elem) {
634 var ea = ' ' + getAttr(elem, attr) + ' ';
635 return (ea.indexOf(tval) >= 0);
636 }
637 },
638 '|=': function(attr, value) {
639 // E[hreflang|="en"]
640 // an E element whose "hreflang" attribute has a
641 // hyphen-separated list of values beginning (from the
642 // left) with "en"
643 value = ' ' + value;
644 return function(elem) {
645 var ea = ' ' + getAttr(elem, attr);
646 return (
647 (ea == value) ||
648 (ea.indexOf(value + '-') == 0)
649 );
650 }
651 },
652 '=': function(attr, value) {
653 return function(elem) {
654 return (getAttr(elem, attr) == value);
655 }
656 }
657 };
658
659 // avoid testing for node type if we can. Defining this in the negative
660 // here to avoid negation in the fast path.
661 var noNextElementSibling = (
662 typeof goog.dom.getDocument().firstChild.nextElementSibling == 'undefined'
663 );
664 var nSibling = !noNextElementSibling ? 'nextElementSibling' : 'nextSibling';
665 var pSibling = !noNextElementSibling ?
666 'previousElementSibling' :
667 'previousSibling';
668 var simpleNodeTest = (noNextElementSibling ? isElement : goog.functions.TRUE);
669
670 var _lookLeft = function(node) {
671 while (node = node[pSibling]) {
672 if (simpleNodeTest(node)) {
673 return false;
674 }
675 }
676 return true;
677 };
678
679 var _lookRight = function(node) {
680 while (node = node[nSibling]) {
681 if (simpleNodeTest(node)) {
682 return false;
683 }
684 }
685 return true;
686 };
687
688 var getNodeIndex = function(node) {
689 var root = node.parentNode;
690 var i = 0,
691 tret = root[childNodesName],
692 ci = (node['_i'] || -1),
693 cl = (root['_l'] || -1);
694
695 if (!tret) {
696 return -1;
697 }
698 var l = tret.length;
699
700 // we calculate the parent length as a cheap way to invalidate the
701 // cache. It's not 100% accurate, but it's much more honest than what
702 // other libraries do
703 if (cl == l && ci >= 0 && cl >= 0) {
704 // if it's legit, tag and release
705 return ci;
706 }
707
708 // else re-key things
709 root['_l'] = l;
710 ci = -1;
711 var te = root['firstElementChild'] || root['firstChild'];
712 for (; te; te = te[nSibling]) {
713 if (simpleNodeTest(te)) {
714 te['_i'] = ++i;
715 if (node === te) {
716 // NOTE:
717 // shortcutting the return at this step in indexing works
718 // very well for benchmarking but we avoid it here since
719 // it leads to potential O(n^2) behavior in sequential
720 // getNodexIndex operations on a previously un-indexed
721 // parent. We may revisit this at a later time, but for
722 // now we just want to get the right answer more often
723 // than not.
724 ci = i;
725 }
726 }
727 }
728 return ci;
729 };
730
731 var isEven = function(elem) {
732 return !((getNodeIndex(elem)) % 2);
733 };
734
735 var isOdd = function(elem) {
736 return (getNodeIndex(elem)) % 2;
737 };
738
739 var pseudos = {
740 'checked': function(name, condition) {
741 return function(elem) {
742 return elem.checked || elem.attributes['checked'];
743 }
744 },
745 'first-child': function() {
746 return _lookLeft;
747 },
748 'last-child': function() {
749 return _lookRight;
750 },
751 'only-child': function(name, condition) {
752 return function(node) {
753 if (!_lookLeft(node)) {
754 return false;
755 }
756 if (!_lookRight(node)) {
757 return false;
758 }
759 return true;
760 };
761 },
762 'empty': function(name, condition) {
763 return function(elem) {
764 // DomQuery and jQuery get this wrong, oddly enough.
765 // The CSS 3 selectors spec is pretty explicit about it, too.
766 var cn = elem.childNodes;
767 var cnl = elem.childNodes.length;
768 // if(!cnl) { return true; }
769 for (var x = cnl - 1; x >= 0; x--) {
770 var nt = cn[x].nodeType;
771 if ((nt === 1) || (nt == 3)) {
772 return false;
773 }
774 }
775 return true;
776 }
777 },
778 'contains': function(name, condition) {
779 var cz = condition.charAt(0);
780 if (cz == '"' || cz == "'") { // Remove quotes.
781 condition = condition.slice(1, -1);
782 }
783 return function(elem) {
784 return (elem.innerHTML.indexOf(condition) >= 0);
785 }
786 },
787 'not': function(name, condition) {
788 var p = getQueryParts(condition)[0];
789 var ignores = { el: 1 };
790 if (p.tag != '*') {
791 ignores.tag = 1;
792 }
793 if (!p.classes.length) {
794 ignores.classes = 1;
795 }
796 var ntf = getSimpleFilterFunc(p, ignores);
797 return function(elem) {
798 return !ntf(elem);
799 }
800 },
801 'nth-child': function(name, condition) {
802 function pi(n) {
803 return parseInt(n, 10);
804 }
805 // avoid re-defining function objects if we can
806 if (condition == 'odd') {
807 return isOdd;
808 } else if (condition == 'even') {
809 return isEven;
810 }
811 // FIXME: can we shorten this?
812 if (condition.indexOf('n') != -1) {
813 var tparts = condition.split('n', 2);
814 var pred = tparts[0] ? ((tparts[0] == '-') ? -1 : pi(tparts[0])) : 1;
815 var idx = tparts[1] ? pi(tparts[1]) : 0;
816 var lb = 0, ub = -1;
817 if (pred > 0) {
818 if (idx < 0) {
819 idx = (idx % pred) && (pred + (idx % pred));
820 } else if (idx > 0) {
821 if (idx >= pred) {
822 lb = idx - idx % pred;
823 }
824 idx = idx % pred;
825 }
826 } else if (pred < 0) {
827 pred *= -1;
828 // idx has to be greater than 0 when pred is negative;
829 // shall we throw an error here?
830 if (idx > 0) {
831 ub = idx;
832 idx = idx % pred;
833 }
834 }
835 if (pred > 0) {
836 return function(elem) {
837 var i = getNodeIndex(elem);
838 return (i >= lb) && (ub < 0 || i <= ub) && ((i % pred) == idx);
839 }
840 } else {
841 condition = idx;
842 }
843 }
844 var ncount = pi(condition);
845 return function(elem) {
846 return (getNodeIndex(elem) == ncount);
847 }
848 }
849 };
850
851 var defaultGetter = (legacyIE) ? function(cond) {
852 var clc = cond.toLowerCase();
853 if (clc == 'class') {
854 cond = 'className';
855 }
856 return function(elem) {
857 return caseSensitive ? elem.getAttribute(cond) : elem[cond] || elem[clc];
858 }
859 } : function(cond) {
860 return function(elem) {
861 return elem && elem.getAttribute && elem.hasAttribute(cond);
862 }
863 };
864
865 var getSimpleFilterFunc = function(query, ignores) {
866 // Generates a node tester function based on the passed query part. The
867 // query part is one of the structures generated by the query parser when it
868 // creates the query AST. The 'ignores' object specifies which (if any)
869 // tests to skip, allowing the system to avoid duplicating work where it
870 // may have already been taken into account by other factors such as how
871 // the nodes to test were fetched in the first place.
872 if (!query) {
873 return goog.functions.TRUE;
874 }
875 ignores = ignores || {};
876
877 var ff = null;
878
879 if (!ignores.el) {
880 ff = agree(ff, isElement);
881 }
882
883 if (!ignores.tag) {
884 if (query.tag != '*') {
885 ff = agree(ff, function(elem) {
886 return (elem && (elem.tagName == query.getTag()));
887 });
888 }
889 }
890
891 if (!ignores.classes) {
892 goog.array.forEach(query.classes, function(cname, idx, arr) {
893 // Get the class name.
894 var re = new RegExp('(?:^|\\s)' + cname + '(?:\\s|$)');
895 ff = agree(ff, function(elem) {
896 return re.test(elem.className);
897 });
898 ff.count = idx;
899 });
900 }
901
902 if (!ignores.pseudos) {
903 goog.array.forEach(query.pseudos, function(pseudo) {
904 var pn = pseudo.name;
905 if (pseudos[pn]) {
906 ff = agree(ff, pseudos[pn](pn, pseudo.value));
907 }
908 });
909 }
910
911 if (!ignores.attrs) {
912 goog.array.forEach(query.attrs, function(attr) {
913 var matcher;
914 var a = attr.attr;
915 // type, attr, matchFor
916 if (attr.type && attrs[attr.type]) {
917 matcher = attrs[attr.type](a, attr.matchFor);
918 } else if (a.length) {
919 matcher = defaultGetter(a);
920 }
921 if (matcher) {
922 ff = agree(ff, matcher);
923 }
924 });
925 }
926
927 if (!ignores.id) {
928 if (query.id) {
929 ff = agree(ff, function(elem) {
930 return (!!elem && (elem.id == query.id));
931 });
932 }
933 }
934
935 if (!ff) {
936 if (!('default' in ignores)) {
937 ff = goog.functions.TRUE;
938 }
939 }
940 return ff;
941 };
942
943 var nextSiblingIterator = function(filterFunc) {
944 return function(node, ret, bag) {
945 while (node = node[nSibling]) {
946 if (noNextElementSibling && (!isElement(node))) {
947 continue;
948 }
949 if (
950 (!bag || _isUnique(node, bag)) &&
951 filterFunc(node)
952 ) {
953 ret.push(node);
954 }
955 break;
956 }
957 return ret;
958 };
959 };
960
961 var nextSiblingsIterator = function(filterFunc) {
962 return function(root, ret, bag) {
963 var te = root[nSibling];
964 while (te) {
965 if (simpleNodeTest(te)) {
966 if (bag && !_isUnique(te, bag)) {
967 break;
968 }
969 if (filterFunc(te)) {
970 ret.push(te);
971 }
972 }
973 te = te[nSibling];
974 }
975 return ret;
976 };
977 };
978
979 // Get an array of child *elements*, skipping text and comment nodes
980 var _childElements = function(filterFunc) {
981 filterFunc = filterFunc || goog.functions.TRUE;
982 return function(root, ret, bag) {
983 var te, x = 0, tret = root[childNodesName];
984 while (te = tret[x++]) {
985 if (
986 simpleNodeTest(te) &&
987 (!bag || _isUnique(te, bag)) &&
988 (filterFunc(te, x))
989 ) {
990 ret.push(te);
991 }
992 }
993 return ret;
994 };
995 };
996
997 // test to see if node is below root
998 var _isDescendant = function(node, root) {
999 var pn = node.parentNode;
1000 while (pn) {
1001 if (pn == root) {
1002 break;
1003 }
1004 pn = pn.parentNode;
1005 }
1006 return !!pn;
1007 };
1008
1009 var _getElementsFuncCache = {};
1010
1011 var getElementsFunc = function(query) {
1012 var retFunc = _getElementsFuncCache[query.query];
1013 // If we've got a cached dispatcher, just use that.
1014 if (retFunc) {
1015 return retFunc;
1016 }
1017 // Else, generate a new one.
1018
1019 // NOTE:
1020 // This function returns a function that searches for nodes and
1021 // filters them. The search may be specialized by infix operators
1022 // (">", "~", or "+") else it will default to searching all
1023 // descendants (the " " selector). Once a group of children is
1024 // found, a test function is applied to weed out the ones we
1025 // don't want. Many common cases can be fast-pathed. We spend a
1026 // lot of cycles to create a dispatcher that doesn't do more work
1027 // than necessary at any point since, unlike this function, the
1028 // dispatchers will be called every time. The logic of generating
1029 // efficient dispatchers looks like this in pseudo code:
1030 //
1031 // # if it's a purely descendant query (no ">", "+", or "~" modifiers)
1032 // if infixOperator == " ":
1033 // if only(id):
1034 // return def(root):
1035 // return d.byId(id, root);
1036 //
1037 // elif id:
1038 // return def(root):
1039 // return filter(d.byId(id, root));
1040 //
1041 // elif cssClass && getElementsByClassName:
1042 // return def(root):
1043 // return filter(root.getElementsByClassName(cssClass));
1044 //
1045 // elif only(tag):
1046 // return def(root):
1047 // return root.getElementsByTagName(tagName);
1048 //
1049 // else:
1050 // # search by tag name, then filter
1051 // return def(root):
1052 // return filter(root.getElementsByTagName(tagName||"*"));
1053 //
1054 // elif infixOperator == ">":
1055 // # search direct children
1056 // return def(root):
1057 // return filter(root.children);
1058 //
1059 // elif infixOperator == "+":
1060 // # search next sibling
1061 // return def(root):
1062 // return filter(root.nextElementSibling);
1063 //
1064 // elif infixOperator == "~":
1065 // # search rightward siblings
1066 // return def(root):
1067 // return filter(nextSiblings(root));
1068
1069 var io = query.infixOper;
1070 var oper = (io ? io.oper : '');
1071 // The default filter func which tests for all conditions in the query
1072 // part. This is potentially inefficient, so some optimized paths may
1073 // re-define it to test fewer things.
1074 var filterFunc = getSimpleFilterFunc(query, { el: 1 });
1075 var qt = query.tag;
1076 var wildcardTag = ('*' == qt);
1077 var ecs = goog.dom.getDocument()['getElementsByClassName'];
1078
1079 if (!oper) {
1080 // If there's no infix operator, then it's a descendant query. ID
1081 // and "elements by class name" variants can be accelerated so we
1082 // call them out explicitly:
1083 if (query.id) {
1084 // Testing shows that the overhead of goog.functions.TRUE() is
1085 // acceptable and can save us some bytes vs. re-defining the function
1086 // everywhere.
1087 filterFunc = (!query.loops && wildcardTag) ?
1088 goog.functions.TRUE :
1089 getSimpleFilterFunc(query, { el: 1, id: 1 });
1090
1091 retFunc = function(root, arr) {
1092 var te = goog.dom.getDomHelper(root).getElement(query.id);
1093 if (!te || !filterFunc(te)) {
1094 return;
1095 }
1096 if (9 == root.nodeType) { // If root's a doc, we just return directly.
1097 return getArr(te, arr);
1098 } else { // otherwise check ancestry
1099 if (_isDescendant(te, root)) {
1100 return getArr(te, arr);
1101 }
1102 }
1103 }
1104 } else if (
1105 ecs &&
1106 // isAlien check. Workaround for Prototype.js being totally evil/dumb.
1107 /\{\s*\[native code\]\s*\}/.test(String(ecs)) &&
1108 query.classes.length &&
1109 // WebKit bug where quirks-mode docs select by class w/o case
1110 // sensitivity.
1111 !cssCaseBug
1112 ) {
1113 // it's a class-based query and we've got a fast way to run it.
1114
1115 // ignore class and ID filters since we will have handled both
1116 filterFunc = getSimpleFilterFunc(query, { el: 1, classes: 1, id: 1 });
1117 var classesString = query.classes.join(' ');
1118 retFunc = function(root, arr) {
1119 var ret = getArr(0, arr), te, x = 0;
1120 var tret = root.getElementsByClassName(classesString);
1121 while ((te = tret[x++])) {
1122 if (filterFunc(te, root)) {
1123 ret.push(te);
1124 }
1125 }
1126 return ret;
1127 };
1128
1129 } else if (!wildcardTag && !query.loops) {
1130 // it's tag only. Fast-path it.
1131 retFunc = function(root, arr) {
1132 var ret = getArr(0, arr), te, x = 0;
1133 var tret = root.getElementsByTagName(query.getTag());
1134 while ((te = tret[x++])) {
1135 ret.push(te);
1136 }
1137 return ret;
1138 };
1139 } else {
1140 // the common case:
1141 // a descendant selector without a fast path. By now it's got
1142 // to have a tag selector, even if it's just "*" so we query
1143 // by that and filter
1144 filterFunc = getSimpleFilterFunc(query, { el: 1, tag: 1, id: 1 });
1145 retFunc = function(root, arr) {
1146 var ret = getArr(0, arr), te, x = 0;
1147 // we use getTag() to avoid case sensitivity issues
1148 var tret = root.getElementsByTagName(query.getTag());
1149 while (te = tret[x++]) {
1150 if (filterFunc(te, root)) {
1151 ret.push(te);
1152 }
1153 }
1154 return ret;
1155 };
1156 }
1157 } else {
1158 // the query is scoped in some way. Instead of querying by tag we
1159 // use some other collection to find candidate nodes
1160 var skipFilters = { el: 1 };
1161 if (wildcardTag) {
1162 skipFilters.tag = 1;
1163 }
1164 filterFunc = getSimpleFilterFunc(query, skipFilters);
1165 if ('+' == oper) {
1166 retFunc = nextSiblingIterator(filterFunc);
1167 } else if ('~' == oper) {
1168 retFunc = nextSiblingsIterator(filterFunc);
1169 } else if ('>' == oper) {
1170 retFunc = _childElements(filterFunc);
1171 }
1172 }
1173 // cache it and return
1174 return _getElementsFuncCache[query.query] = retFunc;
1175 };
1176
1177 var filterDown = function(root, queryParts) {
1178 // NOTE:
1179 // this is the guts of the DOM query system. It takes a list of
1180 // parsed query parts and a root and finds children which match
1181 // the selector represented by the parts
1182 var candidates = getArr(root), qp, x, te, qpl = queryParts.length, bag, ret;
1183
1184 for (var i = 0; i < qpl; i++) {
1185 ret = [];
1186 qp = queryParts[i];
1187 x = candidates.length - 1;
1188 if (x > 0) {
1189 // if we have more than one root at this level, provide a new
1190 // hash to use for checking group membership but tell the
1191 // system not to post-filter us since we will already have been
1192 // guaranteed to be unique
1193 bag = {};
1194 ret.nozip = true;
1195 }
1196 var gef = getElementsFunc(qp);
1197 for (var j = 0; te = candidates[j]; j++) {
1198 // for every root, get the elements that match the descendant
1199 // selector, adding them to the 'ret' array and filtering them
1200 // via membership in this level's bag. If there are more query
1201 // parts, then this level's return will be used as the next
1202 // level's candidates
1203 gef(te, ret, bag);
1204 }
1205 if (!ret.length) { break; }
1206 candidates = ret;
1207 }
1208 return ret;
1209 };
1210
1211 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1212 // the query runner
1213 ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1214
1215 // these are the primary caches for full-query results. The query
1216 // dispatcher functions are generated then stored here for hash lookup in
1217 // the future
1218 var _queryFuncCacheDOM = {},
1219 _queryFuncCacheQSA = {};
1220
1221 // this is the second level of splitting, from full-length queries (e.g.,
1222 // 'div.foo .bar') into simple query expressions (e.g., ['div.foo',
1223 // '.bar'])
1224 var getStepQueryFunc = function(query) {
1225 var qparts = getQueryParts(goog.string.trim(query));
1226
1227 // if it's trivial, avoid iteration and zipping costs
1228 if (qparts.length == 1) {
1229 // We optimize this case here to prevent dispatch further down the
1230 // chain, potentially slowing things down. We could more elegantly
1231 // handle this in filterDown(), but it's slower for simple things
1232 // that need to be fast (e.g., '#someId').
1233 var tef = getElementsFunc(qparts[0]);
1234 return function(root) {
1235 var r = tef(root, []);
1236 if (r) { r.nozip = true; }
1237 return r;
1238 }
1239 }
1240
1241 // otherwise, break it up and return a runner that iterates over the parts
1242 // recursively
1243 return function(root) {
1244 return filterDown(root, qparts);
1245 }
1246 };
1247
1248 // NOTES:
1249 // * we can't trust QSA for anything but document-rooted queries, so
1250 // caching is split into DOM query evaluators and QSA query evaluators
1251 // * caching query results is dirty and leak-prone (or, at a minimum,
1252 // prone to unbounded growth). Other toolkits may go this route, but
1253 // they totally destroy their own ability to manage their memory
1254 // footprint. If we implement it, it should only ever be with a fixed
1255 // total element reference # limit and an LRU-style algorithm since JS
1256 // has no weakref support. Caching compiled query evaluators is also
1257 // potentially problematic, but even on large documents the size of the
1258 // query evaluators is often < 100 function objects per evaluator (and
1259 // LRU can be applied if it's ever shown to be an issue).
1260 // * since IE's QSA support is currently only for HTML documents and even
1261 // then only in IE 8's 'standards mode', we have to detect our dispatch
1262 // route at query time and keep 2 separate caches. Ugg.
1263
1264 var qsa = 'querySelectorAll';
1265
1266 // some versions of Safari provided QSA, but it was buggy and crash-prone.
1267 // We need to detect the right 'internal' webkit version to make this work.
1268 var qsaAvail = (
1269 !!goog.dom.getDocument()[qsa] &&
1270 // see #5832
1271 (!goog.userAgent.WEBKIT || goog.userAgent.isVersionOrHigher('526'))
1272 );
1273
1274 /** @param {boolean=} opt_forceDOM */
1275 var getQueryFunc = function(query, opt_forceDOM) {
1276
1277 if (qsaAvail) {
1278 // if we've got a cached variant and we think we can do it, run it!
1279 var qsaCached = _queryFuncCacheQSA[query];
1280 if (qsaCached && !opt_forceDOM) {
1281 return qsaCached;
1282 }
1283 }
1284
1285 // else if we've got a DOM cached variant, assume that we already know
1286 // all we need to and use it
1287 var domCached = _queryFuncCacheDOM[query];
1288 if (domCached) {
1289 return domCached;
1290 }
1291
1292 // TODO:
1293 // today we're caching DOM and QSA branches separately so we
1294 // recalc useQSA every time. If we had a way to tag root+query
1295 // efficiently, we'd be in good shape to do a global cache.
1296
1297 var qcz = query.charAt(0);
1298 var nospace = (-1 == query.indexOf(' '));
1299
1300 // byId searches are wicked fast compared to QSA, even when filtering
1301 // is required
1302 if ((query.indexOf('#') >= 0) && (nospace)) {
1303 opt_forceDOM = true;
1304 }
1305
1306 var useQSA = (
1307 qsaAvail && (!opt_forceDOM) &&
1308 // as per CSS 3, we can't currently start w/ combinator:
1309 // http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-selectors/#w3cselgrammar
1310 (specials.indexOf(qcz) == -1) &&
1311 // IE's QSA impl sucks on pseudos
1312 (!legacyIE || (query.indexOf(':') == -1)) &&
1313
1314 (!(cssCaseBug && (query.indexOf('.') >= 0))) &&
1315
1316 // FIXME:
1317 // need to tighten up browser rules on ':contains' and '|=' to
1318 // figure out which aren't good
1319 (query.indexOf(':contains') == -1) &&
1320 (query.indexOf('|=') == -1) // some browsers don't understand it
1321 );
1322
1323 // TODO:
1324 // if we've got a descendant query (e.g., '> .thinger' instead of
1325 // just '.thinger') in a QSA-able doc, but are passed a child as a
1326 // root, it should be possible to give the item a synthetic ID and
1327 // trivially rewrite the query to the form '#synid > .thinger' to
1328 // use the QSA branch
1329
1330
1331 if (useQSA) {
1332 var tq = (specials.indexOf(query.charAt(query.length - 1)) >= 0) ?
1333 (query + ' *') : query;
1334 return _queryFuncCacheQSA[query] = function(root) {
1335 try {
1336 // the QSA system contains an egregious spec bug which
1337 // limits us, effectively, to only running QSA queries over
1338 // entire documents. See:
1339 // http://ejohn.org/blog/thoughts-on-queryselectorall/
1340 // despite this, we can also handle QSA runs on simple
1341 // selectors, but we don't want detection to be expensive
1342 // so we're just checking for the presence of a space char
1343 // right now. Not elegant, but it's cheaper than running
1344 // the query parser when we might not need to
1345 if (!((9 == root.nodeType) || nospace)) {
1346 throw new Error('');
1347 }
1348 var r = root[qsa](tq);
1349 // IE QSA queries may incorrectly include comment nodes, so we throw
1350 // the zipping function into 'remove' comments mode instead of the
1351 // normal 'skip it' which every other QSA-clued browser enjoys
1352 // skip expensive duplication checks and just wrap in an array.
1353 if (legacyIE) {
1354 r.commentStrip = true;
1355 } else {
1356 r.nozip = true;
1357 }
1358 return r;
1359 } catch (e) {
1360 // else run the DOM branch on this query, ensuring that we
1361 // default that way in the future
1362 return getQueryFunc(query, true)(root);
1363 }
1364 }
1365 } else {
1366 // DOM branch
1367 var parts = query.split(/\s*,\s*/);
1368 return _queryFuncCacheDOM[query] = ((parts.length < 2) ?
1369 // if not a compound query (e.g., '.foo, .bar'), cache and return a
1370 // dispatcher
1371 getStepQueryFunc(query) :
1372 // if it *is* a complex query, break it up into its
1373 // constituent parts and return a dispatcher that will
1374 // merge the parts when run
1375 function(root) {
1376 var pindex = 0, // avoid array alloc for every invocation
1377 ret = [],
1378 tp;
1379 while (tp = parts[pindex++]) {
1380 ret = ret.concat(getStepQueryFunc(tp)(root));
1381 }
1382 return ret;
1383 }
1384 );
1385 }
1386 };
1387
1388 var _zipIdx = 0;
1389
1390 // NOTE:
1391 // this function is Moo inspired, but our own impl to deal correctly
1392 // with XML in IE
1393 var _nodeUID = legacyIE ? function(node) {
1394 if (caseSensitive) {
1395 // XML docs don't have uniqueID on their nodes
1396 return node.getAttribute('_uid') ||
1397 node.setAttribute('_uid', ++_zipIdx) || _zipIdx;
1398
1399 } else {
1400 return node.uniqueID;
1401 }
1402 } :
1403 function(node) {
1404 return (node['_uid'] || (node['_uid'] = ++_zipIdx));
1405 };
1406
1407 // determine if a node in is unique in a 'bag'. In this case we don't want
1408 // to flatten a list of unique items, but rather just tell if the item in
1409 // question is already in the bag. Normally we'd just use hash lookup to do
1410 // this for us but IE's DOM is busted so we can't really count on that. On
1411 // the upside, it gives us a built in unique ID function.
1412 var _isUnique = function(node, bag) {
1413 if (!bag) {
1414 return 1;
1415 }
1416 var id = _nodeUID(node);
1417 if (!bag[id]) {
1418 return bag[id] = 1;
1419 }
1420 return 0;
1421 };
1422
1423 // attempt to efficiently determine if an item in a list is a dupe,
1424 // returning a list of 'uniques', hopefully in document order
1425 var _zipIdxName = '_zipIdx';
1426 var _zip = function(arr) {
1427 if (arr && arr.nozip) {
1428 return arr;
1429 }
1430 var ret = [];
1431 if (!arr || !arr.length) {
1432 return ret;
1433 }
1434 if (arr[0]) {
1435 ret.push(arr[0]);
1436 }
1437 if (arr.length < 2) {
1438 return ret;
1439 }
1440
1441 _zipIdx++;
1442
1443 // we have to fork here for IE and XML docs because we can't set
1444 // expandos on their nodes (apparently). *sigh*
1445 if (legacyIE && caseSensitive) {
1446 var szidx = _zipIdx + '';
1447 arr[0].setAttribute(_zipIdxName, szidx);
1448 for (var x = 1, te; te = arr[x]; x++) {
1449 if (arr[x].getAttribute(_zipIdxName) != szidx) {
1450 ret.push(te);
1451 }
1452 te.setAttribute(_zipIdxName, szidx);
1453 }
1454 } else if (legacyIE && arr.commentStrip) {
1455 try {
1456 for (var x = 1, te; te = arr[x]; x++) {
1457 if (isElement(te)) {
1458 ret.push(te);
1459 }
1460 }
1461 } catch (e) { /* squelch */ }
1462 } else {
1463 if (arr[0]) {
1464 arr[0][_zipIdxName] = _zipIdx;
1465 }
1466 for (var x = 1, te; te = arr[x]; x++) {
1467 if (arr[x][_zipIdxName] != _zipIdx) {
1468 ret.push(te);
1469 }
1470 te[_zipIdxName] = _zipIdx;
1471 }
1472 }
1473 return ret;
1474 };
1475
1476 /**
1477 * The main executor. Type specification from above.
1478 * @param {string|Array} query The query.
1479 * @param {(string|Node)=} root The root.
1480 * @return {!Array} The elements that matched the query.
1481 */
1482 var query = function(query, root) {
1483 // NOTE: elementsById is not currently supported
1484 // NOTE: ignores xpath-ish queries for now
1485
1486 //Set list constructor to desired value. This can change
1487 //between calls, so always re-assign here.
1488
1489 if (!query) {
1490 return [];
1491 }
1492
1493 if (query.constructor == Array) {
1494 return /** @type {!Array} */ (query);
1495 }
1496
1497 if (!goog.isString(query)) {
1498 return [query];
1499 }
1500
1501 if (goog.isString(root)) {
1502 root = goog.dom.getElement(root);
1503 if (!root) {
1504 return [];
1505 }
1506 }
1507
1508 root = root || goog.dom.getDocument();
1509 var od = root.ownerDocument || root.documentElement;
1510
1511 // throw the big case sensitivity switch
1512
1513 // NOTE:
1514 // Opera in XHTML mode doesn't detect case-sensitivity correctly
1515 // and it's not clear that there's any way to test for it
1516 caseSensitive =
1517 root.contentType && root.contentType == 'application/xml' ||
1518 goog.userAgent.OPERA &&
1519 (root.doctype || od.toString() == '[object XMLDocument]') ||
1520 !!od &&
1521 (legacyIE ? od.xml : (root.xmlVersion || od.xmlVersion));
1522
1523 // NOTE:
1524 // adding 'true' as the 2nd argument to getQueryFunc is useful for
1525 // testing the DOM branch without worrying about the
1526 // behavior/performance of the QSA branch.
1527 var r = getQueryFunc(query)(root);
1528
1529 // FIXME(slightlyoff):
1530 // need to investigate this branch WRT dojo:#8074 and dojo:#8075
1531 if (r && r.nozip) {
1532 return r;
1533 }
1534 return _zip(r);
1535 }
1536
1537 // FIXME: need to add infrastructure for post-filtering pseudos, ala :last
1538 query.pseudos = pseudos;
1539
1540 return query;
1541})();
1542
1543// TODO(arv): Please don't export here since it clobbers dead code elimination.
1544goog.exportSymbol('goog.dom.query', goog.dom.query);
1545goog.exportSymbol('goog.dom.query.pseudos', goog.dom.query.pseudos);

Overview
